The **2026 FIFA World Cup** ([Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish
language"): _Copa mundial de la FIFA de 2026_ ; [French](/wiki/French_language
"French language"): _Coupe du monde de la FIFA de 2026_) will be the 23rd
[FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup"), the quadrennial
international men's [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association
football") championship contested by the [national
teams](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_national_association_football_teams "List of
men's national association football teams") of the member associations of
[FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA"). The tournament will be jointly hosted by 16 cities
in three North American countries; 60 matches, including the quarterfinals,
semi-finals, and the final, will be hosted by the United States while
neighboring Canada and Mexico will each host 10 matches. The tournament will
be the first hosted by three nations.[1][2]

The [United 2026 bid](/wiki/United_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid "United 2026 FIFA
World Cup bid") beat a [rival bid by
Morocco](/wiki/Morocco_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid "Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup
bid") during a final vote at the 68th [FIFA Congress](/wiki/FIFA_Congress
"FIFA Congress") in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow"). It will be the first
World Cup since [South Korea/Japan in 2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002
FIFA World Cup") that will be hosted by more than one nation. With its past
hosting of the [1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World Cup") and
[1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup") tournaments, Mexico
will also become the first country to host all or part of three men's World
Cups.

The 2026 World Cup will also see the tournament expanded from 32 to 48
teams.[3]

## Format[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Format")]

[Michel Platini](/wiki/Michel_Platini "Michel Platini"), who was then the
[UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") [president](/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_UEFA "List
of Presidents of UEFA"), had suggested in October 2013 an expansion of the
tournament to 40 teams,[4][5] an idea that FIFA president [Gianni
Infantino](/wiki/Gianni_Infantino "Gianni Infantino") also suggested in March
2016.[6] A desire to increase the number of participants in the tournament
from the previous 32 team format was announced on October 4, 2016. Four
expansion options were considered:[7][8][9][10]

  * Expand to 40 teams (8 groups of 5 teams) – 88 matches
  * Expand to 40 teams (10 groups of 4 teams) – 76 matches
  * Expand to 48 teams (opening 32-team playoff round) – 80 matches
  * **Expand to 48 teams (16 groups of 3 teams) – 80 matches**

On January 10, 2017, the [FIFA Council](/wiki/FIFA_Council "FIFA Council")
voted unanimously to expand to a 48-team tournament.[3]

The tournament will open with a group stage consisting of 16 groups of three
teams, with the top two teams progressing from each group to a [knockout
tournament](/wiki/Elimination_tournament "Elimination tournament") starting
with a round of 32 teams.[11] The number of games played overall will increase
from 64 to 80, but the number of games played by finalists remains at seven,
the same as with 32 teams, but one group match will be replaced by a knockout
match. The tournament will also be completed within 32 days, the same as
previous 32-team tournaments.[12]

The [European Club Association](/wiki/European_Club_Association "European Club
Association") and its member clubs opposed the proposal for expansion, saying
that the number of games was already at an "unacceptable" level and they urged
the governing body to reconsider its idea of increasing the number of teams
that qualify.[13] They contended that it was a decision taken for political
reasons because Infantino would thus satisfy his electorate, rather than for
sporting reasons.[14] [Liga de Fútbol
Profesional](/wiki/Liga_de_F%C3%BAtbol_Profesional "Liga de Fútbol
Profesional") president [Javier Tebas](/wiki/Javier_Tebas "Javier Tebas")
agreed, affirming the unacceptability of the new format. He told
_[Marca](/wiki/Marca_\(newspaper\) "Marca \(newspaper\)")_ that the football
industry is maintained thanks to clubs and leagues, not FIFA, and that
Infantino did politics because to be elected he promised more countries in the
World Cup; he wanted to keep the electoral promises.[15] German national team
coach [Joachim Löw](/wiki/Joachim_L%C3%B6w "Joachim Löw") warned that
expansion, as had occurred for [Euro 2016](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016 "UEFA Euro
2016"), would dilute the value of the world tournament because players have
already reached their physical and mental limit.[16] Another criticism of the
new format is that with three-team groups, the risk of collusion between the
two teams playing in the last round of the group stage will increase compared
with four-team groups (where simultaneous kick-offs have been employed). One
suggestion by president Infantino is that group matches that end in draws will
be decided by penalty shootouts.[17]

### Slot
allocation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Slot allocation")]

On March 30, 2017, the Bureau of the [FIFA Council](/wiki/FIFA_Council "FIFA
Council") (composed of the FIFA president and the presidents of each of the
six confederations) proposed a slot allocation for the 2026 FIFA World Cup.
The recommendation was submitted for the ratification by the [FIFA
Council](/wiki/FIFA_Council "FIFA Council").[18][19]

On May 9, 2017, two days before the 67th [FIFA Congress](/wiki/FIFA_Congress
"FIFA Congress"), the FIFA Council approved the slot allocation in a meeting
in [Manama](/wiki/Manama "Manama"), Bahrain. It includes an intercontinental
playoff tournament involving six teams to decide the last two FIFA World Cup
berths.[20]

Confederation  | FIFA eligible members  | Places in finals  
(including hosts)  | Percentage of members   
with places in finals  | Places before 2026  
(excluding hosts,  
including half-places)  
---|---|---|---|---  
[AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football Confederation") | 46  | 8 | 17% | 4.5   
[CAF](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African Football") | 54  | 9 | 17% | 5   
[CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF") | 35  | 6 | 17% | 3.5   
[CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL") | 10  | 6 | 60% | 4.5   
[OFC](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football Confederation") | 11  | 1 | 9% | 0.5   
[UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") | 55  | 16 | 29% | 13   
Playoff  | –  | 2 | 33% | –   
Total  | 211  | 48 | 23% | 31 (+ hosts)   
  
The issue of how to allocate automatic host country qualification given that
there are multiple host countries has not yet been resolved and will be
decided by the FIFA council.[18][20][21] The United bid anticipated all three
host countries being awarded automatic places.[22]

The ratification of slot allocation gives
[OFC](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football Confederation") a
guaranteed berth in the final tournament for the first time in FIFA World Cup
history. The 2026 FIFA World Cup will be the first tournament in which all six
confederations have guaranteed berths.

#### Playoff
tournament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Playoff tournament")]

A playoff tournament involving six teams will be held to decide the last two
FIFA World Cup berths,[18] consisting of one team per confederation (except
for [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA")) and one additional team from the confederation
of the host country (i.e. [CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF")).

Two of the teams will be seeded based on the [FIFA World
Rankings](/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings "FIFA World Rankings"), and the seeded
teams will play for a [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup")
berth against the winners of the first two knockout games involving the four
unseeded teams.

The tournament is to be played in the host country(ies) and to be used as a
test event for the FIFA World Cup. The existing playoff window of November
2025 has been suggested as a tentative date for the 2026 edition.

### Host
selection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Host selection")]

Main articles: [Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup
bid](/wiki/Morocco_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid "Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup bid")
and [United 2026 FIFA World Cup bid](/wiki/United_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid
"United 2026 FIFA World Cup bid")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/World_Map_FIFA2.svg/400px-
World_Map_FIFA2.svg.png)](/wiki/File:World_Map_FIFA2.svg)

[](/wiki/File:World_Map_FIFA2.svg "Enlarge")

Map of the World with the six confederations

The FIFA Council went back and forth between 2013 and 2017 on limitations
within hosting rotation based on the continental confederations. Originally,
it was set that bids to be host would not be allowed from countries belonging
to confederations that hosted the two preceding tournaments. It was
temporarily changed to only prohibit countries belonging to the confederation
that hosted the previous World Cup from bidding to host the following
tournament,[23] before the rule was changed back to its prior state of two
World Cups. However, the FIFA Council did make an exception to potentially
grant eligibility to member associations of the confederation of the second-
to-last host of the FIFA World Cup in the event that none of the received bids
fulfill the strict technical and financial requirements.[24][25] In March
2017, FIFA president [Gianni Infantino](/wiki/Gianni_Infantino "Gianni
Infantino") confirmed that "Europe ([UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA")) and Asia
([AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football Confederation")) are
excluded from the bidding following the selection of
[Russia](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") and
[Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") in 2018 and 2022
respectively."[26] Therefore, the 2026 World Cup could be hosted by one of the
remaining four confederations: [CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF") (North
America; last hosted in [1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World
Cup")), [CAF](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of
African Football") (Africa; last hosted in [2010](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup
"2010 FIFA World Cup")), [CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL") (South America;
last hosted in [2014](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup")), or
[OFC](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football Confederation")
(Oceania, never hosted before), or potentially by UEFA in case no bid from
those four met the requirements.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/World_cup_hosts2.png/220px-
World_cup_hosts2.png)](/wiki/File:World_cup_hosts2.png)

[](/wiki/File:World_cup_hosts2.png "Enlarge")

After the selection, the map of world cup hosts stayed like this. Remember
that some city locations may be wrong

Co-hosting the FIFA World Cup—which had been banned by FIFA after the 2002
World Cup—was approved for the 2026 World Cup, though not limited to a
specific number but instead evaluated on a case-by-case basis. Also by 2026,
the FIFA general secretariat, after consultation with the Competitions
Committee, will have the power to exclude bidders who do not meet the minimum
technical requirements to host the competition.[24]

Canada, Mexico and the United States had all publicly considered bidding for
the tournament separately, but the United joint bid was announced on April 10,
2017. The United bid contacted 48 venues in 43 cities (3 venues in 3 cities in
Mexico, 8 venues in 6 cities in Canada and 37 venues in 34 cities in the
United States). This bid was ultimately cut down to 23 venues in 23 cities (3
in Canada, 3 in Mexico and 17 in the United States; the American venues will
be cut down to 10 for a total of 16 venues for the tournament). Morocco
announced its bid in August 2017, and had 14 proposed venues in 12 cities.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/2026_world_cup_bid_election.png/400px-2026_world_cup_bid_election.png)](/wiki/File:2026_world_cup_bid_election.png)

[](/wiki/File:2026_world_cup_bid_election.png "Enlarge")

Voting results:  Allowed to vote | Banned from voting   
---|---  
Voted for United bid |  Canada/Mexico/United States  
Voted for Moroccan bid |  Morocco  
Voted for neither |  Sanctioned by FIFA  
Abstained from voting |  Not a FIFA member  
  
####
Voting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Voting")]

Main article: [2026 FIFA World Cup bids](/wiki/2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bids "2026
FIFA World Cup bids")

The voting took place on June 13, 2018, during FIFA's annual congress in
Moscow, and it was reopened to all eligible members.[27] The United bid won
receiving 134 valid ballots, while the Morocco bid received 65 valid ballots.
Upon the selection, Canada becomes the fifth country to host both men's and
[women's World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA Women's World
Cup")—the latter was in [2015](/wiki/2015_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "2015 FIFA
Women's World Cup"), Mexico becomes the first country to host three men's
World Cups—previously in [1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World
Cup") and [1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup"), and the
United States becomes the first country to host both men's and women's World
Cup twice each—having hosted the [1994 men's](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994
FIFA World Cup") and the [1999](/wiki/1999_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "1999 FIFA
Women's World Cup") and [2003 women's](/wiki/2003_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup
"2003 FIFA Women's World Cup") World Cups.

##
Qualification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Qualification")]

The 2026 World Cup's qualification process has yet to be decided. The FIFA
Council is expected to decide which hosts, if any, will receive automatic
qualifications to the tournament.[18][20][21] The United Bid personnel
anticipated that all three host countries would be awarded automatic
places.[22]

  * [CAF](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African Football") (Africa): 9 slots
  * [AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football Confederation") (Asia): 8 slots
  * [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") (Europe): 16 slots
  * [CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF") (North and Central America and Caribbean): 3 slots
  * [OFC](/wiki/Oceanian_Football_Confederation "Oceanian Football Confederation") (Oceania): 1 slot
  * [CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL") (South America): 6 slots
  * Playoff: 2 slots

## Candidate cities and
venues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Candidate cities and venues")]

During the bidding process, there were 49 venues in 43 cities contacted to be
part of the bid. 41 cities with 45 venues responded and submitted to be part
of the bid (3 venues in 3 cities in Mexico, 8 venues in 6 cities in Canada and
38 venues in 34 cities in the United States). A first round elimination cut 9
venues and 9 cities, then a second round elimination cut 9 venues in 6 cities,
reducing the total number to 23 venues, each in their own city or metropolitan
area. The 23 candidate cities and venues will be narrowed down to 16 in 2020
or 2021 (3 in Canada, 3 in Mexico, and 10 in the United States):

    A ![dagger](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/Dagger-14-plain.png) denotes a stadium used for previous men's World Cup tournaments (United States and Mexico only)
    A ![double-dagger](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f9/Double-dagger-14-plain.png) denotes an indoor stadium with a fixed or [retractable roof](/wiki/Retractable_roof "Retractable roof").

##
Controversies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Controversies")]

FIFA president [Gianni Infantino](/wiki/Gianni_Infantino "Gianni Infantino")
criticized the U.S. [travel ban](/wiki/Trump_travel_ban "Trump travel ban") on
several [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim_world "Muslim world")-majority nations.
Infantino said, "When it comes to FIFA competitions, any team, including the
supporters and officials of that team, who qualify for a World Cup need to
have access to the country, otherwise there is no World Cup. That is
obvious."[29]

However, assurances were later given by the government that there would be no
such discrimination.[30][31]

U.S. President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") threatened
the countries that intended to support the [Morocco
bid](/wiki/Morocco_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid "Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup bid")
to host the 2026 World Cup, tweeting: "The US has put together a STRONG bid w/
Canada & Mexico for the 2026 World Cup. It would be a shame if countries that
we always support were to lobby against the U.S. bid. Why should we be
supporting these countries when they don’t support us (including at the United
Nations)?"[32]

## Broadcasting
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2026_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Broadcasting rights")]

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/23px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png) Canada – [CTV](/wiki/CTV_Television_Network "CTV Television Network"), [TSN](/wiki/The_Sports_Network "The Sports Network"), [RDS](/wiki/R%C3%A9seau_des_sports "Réseau des sports")[33]
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png) United States – [Fox](/wiki/Fox_Sports_\(United_States\) "Fox Sports \(United States\)"), [Telemundo](/wiki/Telemundo_Deportes "Telemundo Deportes")[34]

On February 12, 2015, Fox, Telemundo, and [Bell Media](/wiki/Bell_Media "Bell
Media")'s rights to the tournament were renewed by FIFA to cover 2026, without
accepting any other bids. _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The
New York Times")_ believed that this extension was intended as compensation
for the rescheduling of the [2022 World Cup](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022
FIFA World Cup") to November-December rather than its traditional June-July
scheduling, which falls during the heart of the regular season for several
major North American sports leagues (including the [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League"); Fox is a
main U.S. rightsholder).[35][36][37]
